summary: Have we been pronouncing Houndour wrong this whole time? Like what if you’re supposed to pronounce it as “hound-dour” as...
body: Have we been pronouncing Houndour wrong this whole time? Like what if you’re supposed to pronounce it as “hound-dour” as in “dour, dreary”? It makes a lot of sense to me, but I just woke up.

reblog.comment: Have we been pronouncing Houndour wrong this whole time? Like what if you’re supposed to pronounce it as “hound-dour” as in “dour, dreary”? It makes a lot of sense to me, but I just woke up.

title: Your egg hatched!
body:
The egg trembles and begins to crack. Slowly, a little head pushes the cracked shell away and the baby Pokémon emerges. It’s a Ducklett!

“I got a fucking duck!” The cyborg seemed very happy about this

blog.description: Kim Danbi gosta de animais, sorvete de baunilha, perfume de lavanda, sua cor favorita é  violet. Gosta de anime, principalmente se for mahou shoujo e temáticas cyber punk. É rapper, dança e é dj nas horas vagas. Não gosta de gente sem educação, drogas e filmes muito violentos.

blog.name: inikavulpixelreviews
blog.title: Let's Talk About Pokemon!
blog.description:
Reviewing my personal opinion on every single Pokemon! Yes, all 809 of them!
(Mostly) Daily Uploads, 3 PM EST.

title: Let’s Talk About Pokemon - Maractus
body:
556: Maractus

Ah yes. It’s one of those Pokemon. The Dunsparce, the Torkoal, the Pokemon that released with a single form and relatively mediocre stats, dooming it to not even casual players using the thing very much. Which is such a shame, because Maractus is totally an underrated Pokemon. It’s all the fun and cuteness that comes with these humanoid Grass types, and while we already had a cactus Pokemon, this one is a different flavor enough to where I like them both about equally for different reasons. And it also serves nicely for how Unova, despite being primarily based in the United States, has a handful of Pokemon that would be in-place for other areas in the Americas. Namely, Maractus has a hollow body and loves to dance, making maraca sounds as it does, hencing its name.

Personal score: 9/10

Oh Maractus. Another Pokemon that deserved better treatment.

[Archive]

summary: 10 Shinies I Don’t Really Like (And How I’d Fix Them) - Gen 1
title: 10 Shinies I Don’t Really Like (And How I’d Fix Them) - Gen 1
body:
I dunno if I’m gonna do the later generations but I figured I’d at least get this started since I have some opinions on shiny pokemon, especially from Gen 1. So let’s get goin’.

1. Eeveelutions

These guys are kind of a doozy. For Eevee and Flareon, I don’t necessarily dislike them, they’re just kind of boring. Jolteon is horrid to look at, though. I am not into that shade of green at all. The white coat of Eevee is okay, but it doesn’t really affect me at all. Same with the gold coat of Flareon. So how would I fix them?

For Eevee, I actually kept its main coat the same and just turned its fluff into a more golden yellow color. With Flareon, I brought the whole idea of fire to the max. I kept the golden color, but moved it to the eyes and the insides of the ears. Its coat is now a scorching red color, and I made its tufts a smokey grey. Jolteon’s change doesn’t have much symbolism behind it. I just like the way it looks with a black coat and a yellow mane.

2. Fem Nidos

Getting the second and final group shot out of the way, we have the Nidos. I see what they’re trying to do here. Conceptually the idea of switching the colors of the Nido genders is amazing, and it works fantastically for the male Nidos. For the females, though, it… really doesn’t. Nidoran and Nidorina are okay, since the sickly pea green is confined to just the inner ears, but when you get to Nidoqueen it’s just horrid. I really want to just take her to a Pokemon Center, she does not look healthy. Solution?

Saturation. Make the purple deeper, and turn the pea green into a more turquoise green. That’s about it, really. They look more like their male counterparts like they wanted to, and they don’t look like they should be hunched over my toilet.

3. Mr. Mime

I… honestly don’t understand the reasoning behind this. Its default colors with the pale pinks and dark blues make it looks like sort of a silly clown, with a little bit of jester in there for good measure. As much as most people hate this Pokemon, with its default colors I have no real problem with it. This green, though, just… doesn’t do it any favors.

The solution is right in the name. It’s called “Mr. Mime” after all, so why not make it actually look like a mime? At the very least it’s better than that terrible green.

4. Tauros

Now, this shiny doesn’t bother me too much. It’s a fine shade of yellow that fits Tauros pretty well. The green clashes horribly with it, though. It’s not even necessarily a bad shade of green, it just doesn’t look good with that yellow.

Going by the last few shinies, you probably would’ve thought that I changed the green. And you wouldn’t be wrong. At first, I was experimenting with different colors to replace the green, but nothing quite looked right. At some point, though, I had the thought that the green mane resembled some kind of grassy cloak, so I decided to run with that and turned the light yellow into a darker, muddy sort of brown, which gives Tauros a much more natural look that fits it much better than the yellow in my opinion.

5. Mewtwo

Despite what my past entries may have you believe, I don’t actually dislike green shinies. Mewtwo is a shiny that I actually like quite a bit from an aesthetic perspective. From a thematic point of view, however, it doesn’t make much sense. It’s meant to be a clone of Mew, whose shiny is blue, so why is Mewtwo green? Even arguing that it’s a failed clone doesn’t make much sense to me.

Because of this, I gave it more of a jade, bluish shade of green. Like I said, I do like the green on Mewtwo, but it just doesn’t fit very well. This finds a way to keep it green, while still keeping the theming of it being a failed clone of Mew.

6. Pikachu

OK no more sugarcoating or benefit of the doubt. I hate shiny Pikachu. Seriously can you even tell that this thing is shiny? Unless you’re some kind of superfan, I really doubt it. Here’s the difference: It’s a slightly darker shade of yellow.

Bam. Electric blue with yellow cheeks. I also lightened up the ears and the little brown tail segment. I don’t care if you love this or hate it it is objectively better than the original shiny because at least with this you can tell it’s shiny.

7. Gengar

Same thing as Pikachu. The difference here being that it’s more desaturated instead of darker.

Instead, we can pull from Mega Gengar. Give it a white body with piercing golden eyes. Nothing else to add I just. Hate shiny Gengar.

8. Snorlax

And last in the line of “didn’t change enough.” I actually don’t mind this one as much as Pikachu or Gengar– the blue is very deep and pretty distinctive, but still it’s not great.

Since Snorlax is supposed to be this sleepy, constantly-hibernating Pokemon, I decided to give it a more night-ish palette, with a more purple body and grey paw-pads. The white is also more night-ish, but also gives it this “abominable snowman” look, which fits its sort of mountainous homes.

9. Dragonite

Another for the “OK but not great” pile. It’s not too inoffensive, honestly. The colors mesh well, and it’s definitely distinctive. I’m not a fan of that shade of green on dragonite, though, and it kind of breaks the theming its prevos set up.

Giving its body a light lavender/pink tone with a white belly and yellow wings fits much better with Dratini and Dragonair, not to mention it kind of makes him look like Barney the Dinosaur. It’s super cute and much more pleasing to look at than the pea soup green from before.

10. Golem

Golem just makes me sad, honestly. The shiny itself isn’t bad but it is a huge missed opportunity. I’ll tell you what I mean– so Geodude and graveler have this really cool gold setup. They  both look like solid, uncut gold, it’s AWESOME. Golem just looks like a turtle with a copper shell. It’s not bad, but it’s just so underwhelming.

This turns the turtle part into the gold, and turns the rock into some normal black rock. Maybe basalt or something, it doesn’t really matter. The point is that Golem itself now looks like another creature made from pure gold, bursting from a stone shell. I also made the claws blue to look sort of diamond-esque, but looking back on it I’m not a super fan of it. It looks pretty nice, but it’s also kind of going a little overboard. I could take it or leave it. I can say, though, that it definitely looks better than old bronze-shell before it.

4. Tauros

Now, this shiny doesn’t bother me too much. It’s a fine shade of yellow that fits Tauros pretty well. The green clashes horribly with it, though. It’s not even necessarily a bad shade of green, it just doesn’t look good with that yellow.

Going by the last few shinies, you probably would’ve thought that I changed the green. And you wouldn’t be wrong. At first, I was experimenting with different colors to replace the green, but nothing quite looked right. At some point, though, I had the thought that the green mane resembled some kind of grassy cloak, so I decided to run with that and turned the light yellow into a darker, muddy sort of brown, which gives Tauros a much more natural look that fits it much better than the yellow in my opinion.

5. Mewtwo

Despite what my past entries may have you believe, I don’t actually dislike green shinies. Mewtwo is a shiny that I actually like quite a bit from an aesthetic perspective. From a thematic point of view, however, it doesn’t make much sense. It’s meant to be a clone of Mew, whose shiny is blue, so why is Mewtwo green? Even arguing that it’s a failed clone doesn’t make much sense to me.

Because of this, I gave it more of a jade, bluish shade of green. Like I said, I do like the green on Mewtwo, but it just doesn’t fit very well. This finds a way to keep it green, while still keeping the theming of it being a failed clone of Mew.

6. Pikachu

OK no more sugarcoating or benefit of the doubt. I hate shiny Pikachu. Seriously can you even tell that this thing is shiny? Unless you’re some kind of superfan, I really doubt it. Here’s the difference: It’s a slightly darker shade of yellow.

Bam. Electric blue with yellow cheeks. I also lightened up the ears and the little brown tail segment. I don’t care if you love this or hate it it is objectively better than the original shiny because at least with this you can tell it’s shiny.

7. Gengar

Same thing as Pikachu. The difference here being that it’s more desaturated instead of darker.

Instead, we can pull from Mega Gengar. Give it a white body with piercing golden eyes. Nothing else to add I just. Hate shiny Gengar.

8. Snorlax

And last in the line of “didn’t change enough.” I actually don’t mind this one as much as Pikachu or Gengar– the blue is very deep and pretty distinctive, but still it’s not great.

Since Snorlax is supposed to be this sleepy, constantly-hibernating Pokemon, I decided to give it a more night-ish palette, with a more purple body and grey paw-pads. The white is also more night-ish, but also gives it this “abominable snowman” look, which fits its sort of mountainous homes.

9. Dragonite

Another for the “OK but not great” pile. It’s not too inoffensive, honestly. The colors mesh well, and it’s definitely distinctive. I’m not a fan of that shade of green on dragonite, though, and it kind of breaks the theming its prevos set up.

Giving its body a light lavender/pink tone with a white belly and yellow wings fits much better with Dratini and Dragonair, not to mention it kind of makes him look like Barney the Dinosaur. It’s super cute and much more pleasing to look at than the pea soup green from before.

10. Golem

Golem just makes me sad, honestly. The shiny itself isn’t bad but it is a huge missed opportunity. I’ll tell you what I mean– so Geodude and graveler have this really cool gold setup. They  both look like solid, uncut gold, it’s AWESOME. Golem just looks like a turtle with a copper shell. It’s not bad, but it’s just so underwhelming.

This turns the turtle part into the gold, and turns the rock into some normal black rock. Maybe basalt or something, it doesn’t really matter. The point is that Golem itself now looks like another creature made from pure gold, bursting from a stone shell. I also made the claws blue to look sort of diamond-esque, but looking back on it I’m not a super fan of it. It looks pretty nice, but it’s also kind of going a little overboard. I could take it or leave it. I can say, though, that it definitely looks better than old bronze-shell before it.

trail.content_raw:
I dunno if I’m gonna do the later generations but I figured I’d at least get this started since I have some opinions on shiny pokemon, especially from Gen 1. So let’s get goin’.

[[MORE]]

1. Eeveelutions

These guys are kind of a doozy. For Eevee and Flareon, I don’t necessarily dislike them, they’re just kind of boring. Jolteon is horrid to look at, though. I am not into that shade of green at all. The white coat of Eevee is okay, but it doesn’t really affect me at all. Same with the gold coat of Flareon. So how would I fix them?

For Eevee, I actually kept its main coat the same and just turned its fluff into a more golden yellow color. With Flareon, I brought the whole idea of fire to the max. I kept the golden color, but moved it to the eyes and the insides of the ears. Its coat is now a scorching red color, and I made its tufts a smokey grey. Jolteon’s change doesn’t have much symbolism behind it. I just like the way it looks with a black coat and a yellow mane.

2. Fem Nidos

Getting the second and final group shot out of the way, we have the Nidos. I see what they’re trying to do here. Conceptually the idea of switching the colors of the Nido genders is amazing, and it works fantastically for the male Nidos. For the females, though, it… really doesn’t. Nidoran and Nidorina are okay, since the sickly pea green is confined to just the inner ears, but when you get to Nidoqueen it’s just horrid. I really want to just take her to a Pokemon Center, she does not look healthy. Solution?

Saturation. Make the purple deeper, and turn the pea green into a more turquoise green. That’s about it, really. They look more like their male counterparts like they wanted to, and they don’t look like they should be hunched over my toilet.

3. Mr. Mime

I… honestly don’t understand the reasoning behind this. Its default colors with the pale pinks and dark blues make it looks like sort of a silly clown, with a little bit of jester in there for good measure. As much as most people hate this Pokemon, with its default colors I have no real problem with it. This green, though, just… doesn’t do it any favors.

The solution is right in the name. It’s called “Mr. Mime” after all, so why not make it actually look like a mime? At the very least it’s better than that terrible green.

4. Tauros

Now, this shiny doesn’t bother me too much. It’s a fine shade of yellow that fits Tauros pretty well. The green clashes horribly with it, though. It’s not even necessarily a bad shade of green, it just doesn’t look good with that yellow.

Going by the last few shinies, you probably would’ve thought that I changed the green. And you wouldn’t be wrong. At first, I was experimenting with different colors to replace the green, but nothing quite looked right. At some point, though, I had the thought that the green mane resembled some kind of grassy cloak, so I decided to run with that and turned the light yellow into a darker, muddy sort of brown, which gives Tauros a much more natural look that fits it much better than the yellow in my opinion.

Even arguing that it’s a failed clone doesn’t make much sense to me.

Because of this, I gave it more of a jade, bluish shade of green. Like I said, I do like the green on Mewtwo, but it just doesn’t fit very well. This finds a way to keep it green, while still keeping the theming of it being a failed clone of Mew.

6. Pikachu

7. Gengar

Instead, we can pull from Mega Gengar. Give it a white body with piercing golden eyes. Nothing else to add I just. Hate shiny Gengar.

8. Snorlax

And last in the line of “didn’t change enough.” I actually don’t mind this one as much as Pikachu or Gengar– the blue is very deep and pretty distinctive, but still it’s not great.

Since Snorlax is supposed to be this sleepy, constantly-hibernating Pokemon, I decided to give it a more night-ish palette, with a more purple body and grey paw-pads. The white is also more night-ish, but also gives it this “abominable snowman” look, which fits its sort of mountainous homes.

9. Dragonite

Giving its body a light lavender/pink tone with a white belly and yellow wings fits much better with Dratini and Dragonair, not to mention it kind of makes him look like Barney the Dinosaur. It’s super cute and much more pleasing to look at than the pea soup green from before.

10. Golem

Golem just makes me sad, honestly. The shiny itself isn’t bad but it is a huge missed opportunity. I’ll tell you what I mean– so Geodude and graveler have this really cool gold setup. They  both look like solid, uncut gold, it’s AWESOME. Golem just looks like a turtle with a copper shell. It’s not bad, but it’s just so underwhelming.

This turns the turtle part into the gold, and turns the rock into some normal black rock. Maybe basalt or something, it doesn’t really matter. The point is that Golem itself now looks like another creature made from pure gold, bursting from a stone shell. I also made the claws blue to look sort of diamond-esque, but looking back on it I’m not a super fan of it. It looks pretty nice, but it’s also kind of going a little overboard. I could take it or leave it. I can say, though, that it definitely looks better than old bronze-shell before it.
